newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.
newsitem.headline: Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.

text.p: STOWAWAYS' FAMILY MUCH RELIEVED
The family of the twin teenage girls found on Cape York after they'd jumped ship with a Malaysian sailor says it's much relieved the girls are heading home to New Zealand today.
Australian authorities have decided to deport the three.
The twins' brother, Andrew Ingham, says since his sisters Sarah and Joanne made front page news the family home's been under seige by the media.
The girls hade been stowed away on the ship since February, and Mr Ingham says the ordeal has been very stressful for the family.
He says everyone at home is very happy and much relieved.
DEMOCRATS CALL FOR DISCLOSURE OF MPS LAND HOLDINGS
Australian Democrats leader Cheryl Kernot says the public has the right to know if MPs stand to gain financially from the Prime Minister's ten-point plan on native title.
Senator Kernot has reiterated her call for Coalition MPs to declare their land holdings, saying she's concerned some Queensland politicians in particular have a conflict of interest.
She says one point in the plan is a proposal to upgrade leaseholds to freehold land.
The Senator says she sees that as giving some people a significant capacity for financial benefit.
Federal Cabinet yesterday endorsed John Howard's plan and backbenchers will consider it next week
GAIN FROM AIRPORT SALE TO BE FACTORED INTO NEXT YEAR'S BUDGET
A spokesman for Federal Finanace minister, John Fahey, says the windfall gain from the Government's three-point-four billion dollar sale of three major airports will go in to next year's budget.
He says the figure won't improve this year's Budget due to be handed down next Tuesday.
The sale of the Brisbane, Melbourne and Perth airports was announced yesterday by the Federal Transport minister.
Bankers Trust economist, David Bassanese, says the sale figure had been factored into this year's figures, so next week's numbers won't be as good as expected.
Mr Bassanese says allowing for the special three billion payment from Telstra, he's expecting a deficit of around one billion dollars.
TWO BEING QUESTIONED OVER FATAL SHOOTING
Two men are being questioned by police over the fatal shooting of a woman near Cranbourne, south east of Melbourne, this morning.
The shooting happened in a semi-rural farm property in Manks Road, in an area known as Five-Ways.
The victim, who was in her mid forties, was believed to have been on the property with two men and a teenage girl at the time of the shooting.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
